metadata.title: Relationship between cerebrospinal fluid flow, ventricles morphology, and DTI properties in internal capsules: differences between Alzheimers disease and normal-pressure hydrocephalus
metadata.abstract: Background: Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) and Alzheimers disease (AD) have some similar clinical features and both involve white matter and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) disorders. Purpose: To compare putative relationships between ventricular morphology, CSF flow, and white matter diffusion in AD and NPH. Material and Methods: Thirty patients (18 with AD and 12 with suspected NPH) were included in the study. All patients underwent a 3-Tesla MRI scan, which included phase-contrast MRI of the aqueduct (to assess the aqueductal CSF stroke volume) and a DTI session (to calculate the fractional anisotropy FA and apparent diffusion coefficient ADC) in the internal capsules). Results: FA was correlated with ventricular volume in the suspected NPH population (P  0.001; r s ¼ 0.88), whereas the ADC was highly correlated with the aqueductal CSF stroke volume in AD (P  0.001; r s ¼ 0.79). Conclusion: Although AD and NPH both involve CSF disorders, the two diseases do not have the same impact on the internal capsules. The magnitude of the ADC is related to the aqueductal CSF stroke volume in AD, whereas FA is related to ventricular volume in NPH.

Introduction.text:
Alzheimers disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the Western world. It involves grey matter and white matter abnormalities, both of which are correlated with indices of cognitive decline (1,2). In AD, ventriculomegaly, white matter lesions, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow disorders can be evidenced by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (3).
Moreover, recent theoretical work has suggested that certain CSF disorders could induce AD (4). Indeed, ventricular enlargement is a morphological sign of AD progression (5,6).
However, these types of morphological and functional changes are not fully specific for AD, since patients with hydrocephalus present the same type of brain lesions (7). Many researchers have assessed the relationship between ventricular enlargement and the severity of AD (8) or hydrocephalus (7). Indeed, ventricular volume increases with disease severity and is associated (notably in hydrocephalus) with changes in parameters measured by diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) (9). Moreover, phase contrast MRI (PCMRI) enables the hydrodynamic assessment of biologic fluids. The aqueductal CSF stroke volume quantifies the volume of fluid passing from the ventricular compartment into the subarachnoid spaces and thus reflects the pressure differences experienced by the ventricular system (10). It has been shown that aqueductal CSF stroke volumes are higher in normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) than in AD (11). It is also well established that AD induces white matter lesions (notably in the internal capsule IC) that can be observed with DTI. However, the cause of this degeneration has yet to be defined (12). In DTI, tissue diffusion properties can be assessed by means of two postprocessed indexes: fractional anisotropy (FA) and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC). Fractional anisotropy reflects the spatial organization of the studied material (with an FA value of 0 indicating an isotropic medium and a value of 1 indicating a linear arrangement), whereas the ADC represents the magnitude of water diffusion. It has been suggested that when intracranial pressure increases, the water diffusion (i.e. the ADC) in the periventricular region will increase because of the transependymal resorption of CSF (13,14). This process produces an increase in the extracellular water content in adjacent tissues (e.g. interstitial edema). Increased diffusion in the periventricular region has been documented in selected clinical cases of NPH and in obstructive hydrocephalus (15). Even though the disease mechanisms in AD and NPH share certain features, the putative relationships between ventricular volume, CSF flow, and diffusion values in periventricular structures (such as the ICs) in AD have not previously been investigated. Here, we examined the links between morphological aspects of lateral ventricles (e.g. volume) and aqueductal CSF stroke volume with diffusion parameters in the ICs in patients with AD and suspected NPH patients.

Material and Methods Patients.text:
A total of 30 patients were enrolled in this prospective study. All participants underwent a comprehensive physical and neurological examination performed by an experienced clinician; including a screen of cognitive functions and disability in activities of daily living.
Eighteen patients with AD (diagnosed according to the NINCDS ADRDA criteria ( 16)) were included (mean age: 78.8 AE 5.3 years). The included AD patients had Mini Mental State Examination score of 20 or more out of 30 (17).
Twelve patients with suspected NPH were also included (mean age, 76.8 AE 8.5 years). This diagnosis was based on the guidelines drawn up by Relkin et al. (18) for probable or possible idiopathic NPH. All patients had ventricular dilatation (confirmed by an experienced radiologist) but no cortical atrophy or aqueductal stenosis. All included NPH patients had at least two of the signs in Hakims triad (including cognitive impairment) (19).
The studys objectives and procedures were approved by the local independent ethics committee and all patients provided their written, informed consent to participation.

Image acquisitions.text:
All images were acquired with a 3T Signa HDx MR scanner (GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA).
Morphological images included two-dimensional (2D) T2-weighted (T2W) axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences (field of view FOV, 24 Â 24 cm 2 ; reconstruction matrix, 384 Â 224; slice thickness, 5 mm; TRTE, 90005 ms) and three-dimensional (3D) BRAVO T1-weighted (T1W) anatomical images (field of view FOV, 25 Â 23 cm 2 ; reconstruction matrix, 256 Â 256; slice thickness, 1.4 mm; TE, 4 ms; TR, 10 ms).
Cerebrospinal fluid flow at the aqueduct of Sylvius was measured on axial images (acquired perpendicular to the direction of CSF flow). Flow was measured quantitatively by 2D velocity-encoded cine-PCMRI (TRTE, 157 ms; FOV, 140 Â 140 mm 2 ; matrix size, 256 Â 128; flip angle, 25 ; one excitation; slice thickness, 5 mm; velocity-encoding value, 10-20 cms). Peripheral gating was used to cover the entire cardiac cycle, with retrospective synchronization of 32 quantitative flow-encoded images per cycle.
DTI was performed with spin-echo echo-planar imaging sequences (SE-EPI) and the following parameters: TRTE, 700090 ms; flip angle, 90 ; one excitation; 12 diffusion gradient directions with b ¼ 1000 smm 2 ; FOV, 280 Â 280 mm; acquisition matrix size, 128 Â 128; slice thickness, 3 mm.

Data analysis.text:
Ventricle volume measurements. For each patient, the lateral ventricle volume was assessed by tracing volumes of interest (VOIs) on each slice of the 2D-T2W and 3D-T1W images. For each sequence, the boundaries of the VOIs were defined semi-automatically with the level-set tool provided by MIPAV (20). Ventricular volume was defined as the mean of the left and right measurements.
Aqueductal CSF flow measurements. The PCMRI data were analyzed using in-house image processing software (see http:www.tidam.fr). An optimized CSF flow segmentation algorithm was used to semi-automatically extract the region of interest (ROI) and compute the aqueductal CSF stroke volume (21). In order to assess the variability of this volume measurement, two different observers applied this semi-automatic method. DTI analysis. After correction for eddy currents and head motion, FA and ADC maps were computed using FSL software (see http:www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk fsl) (22).
Volumes of interest (VOIs) were manually defined on three consecutive slices of each IC (Fig. 1). The FA and ADC values were measured by averaging these volumes of interest. Axial diffusivity (the first eigenvalue) and radial diffusivity (the mean of the second and third eigenvalues) were also calculated.

Statistics and validation..text:
To check for the absence of agerelated bias, the groups age distributions were compared in a Mann-Whitney test. The same test was also used to perform intergroup comparisons of the ventricular volume and aqueductal CSF stroke volume.
Correlations between FA and ADC on one hand and ventricular volume and aqueductal CSF stroke volume on the other were computed in a two-sided Spearmans rank correlation test. The respective contributions of axial and radial diffusivities were also studied.
Variability in CSF stroke volume measurement was assessed by computing the linear regression between the values calculated by the two observers. Moreover, a Wilcoxons test was applied to access the significance of any differences.
For the internal validation of significant models, 500 bootstrap replications were applied. Bootstrap c-statistics were calculated in order to assess the final models predictive power (23).
To study potential differences between left-and right-side white matter characteristics in the IC, a Wilcoxon test was used to compare the corresponding FA, ADC, axial diffusivity, and radial diffusivity values. All statistical analyses were performed with R 2.15 software (http:www.r-project.orgfoundation).

Results.text:
There was no difference between the groups age distributions.
Fig. 2 shows PCMRI data for an AD patient (Fig. 2b) and a patient with suspected NPH (Fig. 2c). The patients CSF flow curves are presented in Figs. 2d and2e, respectively.
For AD patients, the mean ventricular volume was 52.3 AE 25.1 mL and the mean aqueductal CSF stroke volume was 45.4 AE 21.8 mL. In the ICs, the mean FA and ADC values were 0.636 ( AE 0.038) and 8.3.10 À4 (AE 0.8.10 À4 ) mm 2 s, respectively. For suspected NPH patients, the mean ventricular volume was 119.3 AE 48.2 mL and the mean aqueductal CSF stroke volume was 148.9 AE 72.2 mL. In the ICs, the mean FA and ADC values were 0.653 (AE 0.023) and 8.75.10 À4 (AE 0.9.10 À4 ) mm 2 s, respectively. Aqueductal stroke volumes and ventricular volumes were significantly higher in suspected NPH patients than in AD patients (P  0.001).
In the AD group, there was no observed correlation between ventricular volume and FA (Fig. 3). However, we did observe a significant correlation between the ADC and the stroke volume (P  0.001, r s ¼ 0.72). Scatter plots illustrating this correlation are given in Fig. 4. There was significant correlation between aqueductal CSF stroke volume on one hand and axial diffusivity (P ¼ 0.0055, r s ¼ 0.63) and radial diffusivity (P ¼ 0.0015, r s ¼ 0.69) on the other. The corresponding scatter plots are presented in Figs. 5 and6, respectively. A Wilcoxons test revealed that there was no significant difference between the CSF flow values noted by the two observers. Moreover, the linear regression yielded a slope of 1.007 and an inter-observer correlation coefficient of R 2  0.99.
Internal validation of the ADC vs. aqueductal CSF stroke volume model (for AD) gave a 95 confidence interval (CI) of 0.55-1.0.
In suspected NPH, there was a significant correlation between ventricular volume and FA (P  0.001, r s ¼ 0.88) but not between aqueductal CSF stroke volume and the ADC (Figs. 3 and4). A bootstrap analysis of the correlation between ventricular volume and FA yielded a 95 CI of 0.76-1.0.
A Mann-Whitney test did not reveal any intergroup differences in ADC or radial diffusivity. However, axial diffusivity was significantly higher in suspected NPH patients than in AD patients (P ¼ 0.02). There were no left vs. right differences in FA or ADC values in the ICs in either of the two groups.

Discussion.text:
The aim of the present study was to assess the potential relationships between CSF hydrodynamics, ventricle morphology, and white matter characteristics in the periventricular area in AD patients and in suspected NPH patients. First, we found that suspected NPH patients had a higher aqueductal CSF stroke volume and a greater ventricular volume than AD patients did. This was consistent with the literature data on this topic (11,24). A few researchers have assessed DTI parameters in periventricular structures in AD or hydrocephalus. Assaf et al. (25) examined patients with increased intracranial pressure (not chronic idiopathic hydrocephalus) and reported abnormally high FA in white matter regions in the vicinity of the ventricles. Hattingen et al. studied patients with idiopathic hydrocephalus and found similar results for the corticospinal tract (9). However, these studies compared diseased patients with healthy elderly controls. In the present work, we compared DTI results for two diseases in which similar types of brain lesions occur (7). We did not observe intergroup differences in FA in the ICs.
We observed significant differences between AD and suspected NPH in terms of white matter characteristics. Indeed, we found that the shape of the diffusion tensor was not affected by ventricular enlargement in AD but was significantly correlated with the latter parameter in NPH (Fig. 3). Our bootstrap analysis showed that this correlation was stable. We hypothesize that the changes in FA might be related to dilatation of the ventricles and associated damage to adjacent white matter (25,26). However, dilatation alone cannot explain the strong correlation between FA and ventricle size in suspected NPH, since this relationship was not observed in AD patients. Hence, another parameter must be involved in this phenomenon. We also found that the cm²s) Fig. 4. A scatter plot showing the relationship between the (ADC) and aqueductal CSF stroke volume at the internal capsule level for Alzheimer disease and suspected NPH. A Spearmans test revealed significant correlation between these two parameters for Alzheimer patients (P  0.001; r s ¼ 0.72).
ADC was found significantly correlated with aqueductal CSF stroke volume in AD patients (Fig. 4). Once again, internal validation of the model showed that this correlation was stable. This relationship can be explained by the forced-diffusion phenomenon: the higher the stroke volume, the higher the diffusion amplitude (notably via transependymal absorption). By way of an example, Fig. 7 presents axial T2-FLAIR images of the AD patients presenting the two most extreme stroke volumes. Transependymal resorption is clearly higher in Fig. 7b and was associated with the highest stroke volume in the AD group. However, it appears that the effect of convection is limited in range. Indeed, we found that this relationship did not hold for the suspected NPH patients, who had the highest aqueductal CSF stroke volumes. Taken as a whole, these results suggest that white matter damage is related to CSF pulsatility as well as ventricle size. Indeed, the CSF impacts on the ventricular walls at each cardiac cycle; when the aqueductal CSF stroke volume is high, this may enlarge the ventricles and lead to potential periventricular damage. Small stroke volumes and ventricular volumes do not affect the shape and size of the IC. However, ventricular enlargement is limited, since the brain is contained within the (non-expandable) skull. Once the enlargement limit has been reached, pressure on surrounding structures will rise and thus increase the likelihood of damage to white matter.
It is noteworthy that two patients with clinical features of NPH did not have the aqueductal CSF stroke volumes typically encountered in this condition (27). However, our study of flow measurement variability evidenced high reproducibility and so this finding cannot be attributed to errors in the CSF flow calculation. In fact, these data fit with the hypothesis whereby hydrocephalus can be concomitant with other degenerative diseases (such as AD or brain atrophy) (4). A Spearmans test revealed a significant correlation between these two parameters in the AD group (P ¼ 0.0015, r s ¼ 0.69).
elderly subjects has been estimated at 34 mLcardiac cycle (28). The values for our AD patients were slightly higher than this, whereas NPH patients had significantly and abnormally high aqueductal CSF stroke volumes (which are in line with previous reports) (11).
In the present study, we used an ROI-based approach to investigate the changes in FA and ADC. Although the ROI method is easy to perform and readily available to most clinicians, it may be biased by subjectivity. A common alternative is the use of fully automated, voxelwise approaches such as TBSS (29). However, the TBSS method is reportedly not applicable to subjects with large ventricles (29,30). However, Hattingen et al. cross-validated their data using both ROI-based and TBSS approaches and found similar results (9). Thus, our choice of an ROI-based analysis remains valid. Despite the fact that the ventricular dilatation observed in hydrocephalus patients can affect the aspect of white matter on the FA map, we were able to adequately visualize the ICs and designate our ROIs (Fig. 1).
Another potential study limitation relates to patient selection. Our AD and suspected NPH patients were selected according to clinical criteria (notably cognitive function screening for AD and Hakims triad evaluation for NPH). In both diseases, it is difficult to establish accurate diagnostic criteria. Moreover, we did not perform follow-up studies of our patients (notably for suspected NPH) and thus cannot completely rule out the possibility that factors other than hydrocephalus contributed to the clinical symptoms in some of the suspected NPH patients. However, none of the NPH patients had a diagnosed medical condition that better explained the key symptoms than idiopathic hydrocephalus did.
In conclusion, our study showed that although both AD and NPH involve CSF disorders, the two diseases do not have the same impact on the ICs. We found that the magnitude of the diffusion is related to the aqueductal CSF stroke volume in AD, whereas the FA is related to ventricular volume in NPH.
